chapter1.title: Chapter 1: First Year
chapter1.description: Doubts are setting in. A choice must be made

text.speaker: Director
text: Hello, everyone. Welcome to the University of Orleans, a place where imagination meets logic and where every bug is an opportunity for creativity.
This year, as every year, we will explore fascinating areas: from artificial intelligence to distributed systems, from web development to quantum architectures that are still somewhat mysterious.
But beyond languages and frameworks, what we seek to impart to you is critical thinking, curiosity, and the ability to solve problems... even those that seem impossible at first glance. Thank you.

text.speaker: Professor
text.text: I am your formal calculation professor, Antoine Robert. I used to be just like you: a student at this university, sitting in the same seats as you. By listening to lectures and working hard, I managed to get this teaching position. I am now a research professor, which involves...
The protagonist has the choice between continuing to listen to the professor or chatting with the person sitting next to him.
The protagonist keeps listening to his teacher.

text: - ... teaching in schools while conducting research the rest of the time. Now that you know about my background, I will discuss the content of my course.
We will have a final exam at the end of the semester and about ten tutorials and practical classes to prepare for it. Each class will be divided into two parts -...

text.text: The protagonist once again has the choice between continuing to listen to the professor or chatting with the person sitting next to him.
The protagonist starts a conversation with the person sitting next to him.
[I should try to make friends. I turn to my seatmate.]
Hi !

text.speaker: Classmate
text.text: Hi ! Are you from Orleans?
Not at all, I'm from Alsace! And you?

text.speaker: Classmate
text.text: I'm from Orleans. My name is Martin, and you?
[I spend the rest of the class chatting with Martin, and the end of the day arrives before I even realize it.]
Message notification

text.speaker: Martin
text.text: Hi! Do you want to come to the integration party?
The protagonist has the choice between accompanying Martin to the university's integration party or staying home.
The protagonist keeps listening to his teacher.

text.speaker: Professor
text.text: In one, we will approach the course theoretically and illustrate with examples. I expect you to take notes and ask questions as soon as you don't understand something. In the second, I -...
[I listen to Mr. Robert in silence. The rest of the day passes slowly, and I eagerly await the moment when I can go home.]
Smartphone notification

text.speaker: Notification
text.text: The “Student Job” job posting published by Leclerc Orléans matches your profile.
The protagonist has the choice between applying to the job offer or ignoring it.
The protagonist ignores the job offer.

text.speaker: Director
text.text: Thank you all for this year. I have had the pleasure of meeting some very talented students who are brimming with ideas. I am counting on you to continue in the same vein next year. Transcripts are available on the university website.

text.speaker: Transcript of grades
text.text: You have not received approval from the departmental council to enter the second year.
[I wait for the end of the day with a knot in my stomach. It takes me several hours to fully realize what is happening.]

text: [Rejected... I thought it would be a shock... but actually, it's more of a strange mix of feelings. Surprise... and at the same time, not really. In high school, I was good. Really good. Everyone told me I had potential, that I was “cut out for studying.” Yet I completely dropped out.]

[The truth is... I wasn't interested. I tried to convince myself otherwise, I followed the path everyone expected of me, but every class seemed... empty. Far from what I really wanted to do. And of course, because I wasn't motivated... I didn't give it my all. I did the bare minimum, sometimes nothing at all. How could I have succeeded like that? It wasn't for me. And I only realize that now, too late.]

text.text: Message notification

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Hey, sweetheart! Did you get your grades? Are you passing to the second year?
The protagonist has the choice between telling his mother the truth about his failure or lying to her.
The protagonist lies to his parents about his failure.

text: [How could I explain this to my parents? “I failed because I didn't really believe in it”? That sounds so ridiculous... I need to ask myself the right questions.]

What do I want to do? What really motivates me? Continuing down a path that doesn't suit me will only lead to more failures. Well... I need to find something that suits me. And this time... I need to really commit to it.
[I spent the night researching. With Parcoursup closing several weeks ago, it will be very difficult for me to find a program that will accept me.]

[Why didn't I realize I was heading straight for disaster earlier this year? I'm forced to turn to subjects that rarely fill up classes and accept any grades, such as literature or history. I'm far from my ideal, but you never know! Maybe I'm actually cut out for this kind of study. It's totally different from computer science, after all!]

text.text: The protagonist has the choice between reorienting himself toward a BA in literature or history in Orléans.

choices.label: Register for a Bachelor of Arts (BA) in literature
Register for a Bachelor of Arts (BA) in history

text.text: The protagonist tells the truth to his parents.
[I have to face up to it. I'll never be able to make a fresh start if I hide something this important from my own parents.]

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Hi sweetheart! Are you okay? You seem...worried.
Yes... I received the answer regarding my transition to the second year.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: Finally. So? Is it good?
…No. I was refused.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: What? You weren't accepted? But… why?
I… I didn't invest enough in my studies. I had trouble getting interested in what I was doing and… I didn't give my best.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Oh… my dear… We knew it could be tough, but… hearing that hurts.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: We are disappointed, yes! But ... We really believed you could succeed. It's not just about disappointment for you… we're sad to see you suffer and lose confidence.
I'm sorry.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Listen… it's not the end of the world. You made a mistake, that's all. But you need to understand what didn't work to improve the situation. We'll look at the possible options for you together.
I want to give myself fully this time. I don't want to make the same mistakes.

text: [I thought it would be a disaster… that it would end in screams, accusations, ... But… they didn't reject me. They wanted to understand. They listened to me. They even told me they still believe in me.]
[I did well by confessing. In any case, hiding it wouldn't have changed anything… and now, at least, I'm not alone anymore. I feel like I've finally stopped running away.]

I... I'm sorry. I did everything I could, but between classes and work... I couldn't do it anymore. I was coming home too late, I was exhausted, I couldn't even study properly anymore. I tried to keep going, I really did... but I couldn't do it.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: You don’t have to apologize. You fought to get out of it, you worked hard to earn your money and follow your studies. It wasn’t your fault. It was just… too much for you.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: We saw how exhausted you were these past months. You couldn’t carry everything alone. We are proud of you, do you hear? Not disappointed. Proud of your courage.
I thought that... you would be angry with me. That you would be disappointed in me.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: Disappointed? Come on… You worked hard, you took responsibility, you gave your best in a difficult situation. It’s not a shameful failure. Even adults don’t always manage to handle things so well.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: We will think together about what you want to do. Whether it's starting over, changing direction, or lightening your workload... You are not alone.

text: [They... supported me. They really understood. I thought they would be disappointed, that they would blame me for my choices... But they listened to me. They believed me. And they didn't minimize what I had been through.]

[I did the right thing telling them. I had kept it all to myself for so long, carrying this burden alone... I feel lighter now. I am not alone. They are with me, and I will start over without making any more mistakes.]

I... I didn't put enough effort into my studies. I had trouble getting interested in what I was doing and... I didn't give it my best.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Oh... my dear. We knew it could be difficult, but... hearing it hurts.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: We are disappointed, yes! But ... we really believed you could succeed. It's not just about disappointment for you… we're also sad to see you suffer and lose confidence.
I'm sorry.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Listen... it's not the end of the world. You made a mistake, that's all. But you need to realize what went wrong so you can improve the situation. We'll look at the options available to you together.

text: [They... supported me. They really understood. I thought they would be disappointed, that they would blame me for my choices... But they listened to me. They believed me. And they didn't minimize what I had been through.]
[I did the right thing by coming clean. Hiding it wouldn't have changed anything anyway... and now, at least, I'm not alone anymore. I feel like I've finally stopped running away.]

chapter2.title: Chapter 2: Second Year
chapter2.description: A new path opens up. It’s up to you to take it

text.text: The protagonist is reorienting himself.

text: [I'm still in the middle of this new course... and yet I already feel like I'm failing. The worst part is that it has nothing to do with the difficulty. The lessons are simple, I understand everything right away, I do my exercises quickly, almost mechanically. On paper, I'm a good student. But inside... there's nothing.]

[No interest. No desire. I thought a new start would change everything. I thought it was just a matter of fatigue, or poor guidance the first time around. I believed that if I started over somewhere else, if I took it seriously, if I followed the rules, I would finally achieve something. But no. I'm falling back into exactly the same place.]

[I'm slipping again, but this time without excuse. I don't even have the energy to be angry with myself anymore. Just... emptiness. And this feeling that no matter what I do, I'm not making any progress. And now... I only have three options.]

[Keep going until the end of the year, grit my teeth, endure this mentally exhausting training just so I don't lose my scholarship, give up and go work at McDonald's, earn a little money, tell myself that “it's better than nothing,” even if it's not what I want, or give up completely... and do nothing. Stay at home, watch the days go by until the next school year when I can reorient myself.]

text.text: The protagonist has the choice between forcing himself to continue his license, abandoning the courses and going to work or disorienting himself until the next school year.

choices.label: Wait until the next school year

text.text: The protagonist drops out of school for the rest of the year.

text: [I'm scared, of course. Scared of the void, scared of the “what are you doing right now?” question, scared of how others see me. But I'm more tired than scared. Tired of pushing myself, tired of failing, tired of fighting in a direction that isn't mine.]

[I'm going to think about what I really want, stop rushing into choices out of panic. When Parcoursup reopens, I'll look for something that really speaks to me, that suits me. This time I won't make a mistake. I need to talk to my parents about it.]

text.text: I've decided to stop studying for the rest of the year. I'm not going to do anything until Parcoursup reopens. I... I need to take a break and think things through.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: Stop... completely? You mean... stay at home and do nothing?
Yes. I've been forcing myself for too long to do something that doesn't suit me. I want to take the time to figure out what I really want before I start again.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: I understand... but you know it's not easy. Doing nothing can be hard. You might get bored, lose your rhythm.
I know... but I prefer that to continuing to exhaust myself for something that doesn't motivate me. I need this time to reflect and prepare for my real reorientation.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: We're worried about you... but we can also see that you're serious about what you're saying. We'll be there to help you organize this time, to keep you from sinking.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: Exactly. You're taking a step back so you can start again on a stronger footing. We support you. But promise us you'll keep thinking actively about things and use this time for yourself.
I promise.
[I should find out about reorientation.]

text: [I think I've found several courses that seem perfect for me. There's the BUT MMI, which would allow me to showcase my creativity while putting my IT skills into practice.]

[There's also the BTS MCO (operational sales management), which will help me develop my leadership skills. And finally, there's a BTS in tourism that could tie in with the course I'm doing this year. I made these different choices on Parcoursup.]

text: [I have decided to continue this course until the end of the year. I want to persevere, not give up, prove that I can see it through to the end. But... is this really what I want to do with my life?]

[I attend every class, I pass, but I can't seem to muster any interest or passion for it. But... am I continuing here simply for security, or should I try something else? Parcoursup will reopen soon, and maybe I could find something that really interests me. But would I be able to reorient myself once again? I should look into it.]

Yes, I know... but staying here isn't doing me any good. I'm doing well in my classes, but I don't feel like I belong. I need to find a path that really motivates me.

text.speaker: Dad
text.text: It's brave of you to say that. It's not easy to change again. But if you think it's best for you, we'll support you. We've seen how hard you've worked this year. As long as you finish this one, it'll be fine.

text.speaker: Mom
text.text: We'll be there, as always. The important thing is that you do something that moves you forward and makes you happy.
Thank you... I know it's going to be hard, but I really want to give it a try.
